sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews Tonight. I'm Mariam Zaidi and these are the headlines this hour.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia must withdraw its forces from the sovereign territory of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia must stop destabilizing the international security situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukraine tells the UN that it needs action now to stop Russia from moving further into its territory as it prepares to implement a state of emergency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: As the EU formally adopts its package of sanctions against Russia, targeting individuals and all lawmakers who voted to recognise breakaway regions, the bloc calls Putin's actions against Ukraine illegal and unacceptable. President Putin says he is still open to dialogue, but that Russia's security concerns are non-negotiable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And here in the Cube, we look at the ongoing cyber warfare and how the crisis is being displayed across borders.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening. Ukraine is set to declare a state of emergency following Moscow's approval of two breakaway regions,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: as well as its movement of forces onto Ukrainian soil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The measures will see the introduction of stronger security at critical infrastructure facilities and military checkpoints along key transport links.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Unmarked military vehicles have been spotted crossing the border after the Kremlin officially recognised the independence of the Luhansk and Donetsk regions on Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says Kiev's standoff with Russia will decide the future of European security.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Its foreign affairs minister addressing an emergency UN General Assembly session said Kiev needs action now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia must withdraw its forces from the sovereign territory of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia must stop destabilizing the international security situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We Ukrainians want peace and we want to resolve all issues through diplomacy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We stand ready for all possible scenarios and ready to protect our land and our people if Russia further attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The U.S. and NATO say Russia continues to stage a massive invasion force on Ukraine's border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Since the end of last year, security analysts estimate over 100,000 Russian troops have been sent to the region. On January 25th, Russia began joint military drills with Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Those troops were set to leave last weekend.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Belarusian officials said the soldiers would stay indefinitely due to escalating tensions in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Moscow denies its planning an invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, now our correspondent in Kiev, Sasha Vakulina, joins us now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Sasha, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So, a 30-day state of emergency, reservists being called up the army.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ukraine is readying itself for the worst-case scenario?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, definitely it feels like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And in addition to those 36,000 of the reservists, today we've got some new lines with additional 5,000 troops to be called by the National Guard and extra 5,000 more troops to the Border Guard service. So this is not yet the general mobilization, but yet these are the measures announced today. Also, Ukrainian parliament today voted to approve in the first reading the draft law that would allow, that would give the permission to Ukrainians to carry firearms and act in self-defense. These are some of the measures announced today in Kyiv by Ukrainian officials. They have also called on for all the Ukrainians who are currently in Russia to come back immediately and for those who are now not there, not to travel to Russia. Now, Sasha, we're also seeing reports of another cyber attack, this latest one hitting government websites. What more can you tell us about that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Indeed, according to the latest information, it has started this afternoon around 4pm and the cyber attack crashed the websites of the Cabinet of Ministers, the Security Service, the Verhovna Rada, this is therainian parliament ministry of foreign affairs and a few banks the it's still on the investigation has started they're trying to look into it to find more information about the sources where is it coming from and of course the the attack today comes just seven days after the attack that was called already the biggest and the largest in ukraine's history Mariam and Sasha what's the mood like in the capital are people resigned the possibility of a full-scale invasion I would say that the mood here about the possible invasion is getting more and more worrying every day these are the conversations that you can hear just walking down the streets of Kiev and other cities in Ukraine. What Ukrainians do try to do nowadays, they try to be resilient and they try to be as consolidated as possible. And on that one today, one of the charities in the country, the fund called Come Back Alive announced that just over one day, over 24 hours, Ukrainians donated more for Ukrainian army than they did in the whole 2021.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: There was more than 600,000 euros in donations in just 24 hours by the population of Ukraine for the army.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Sasha, thank you so much for that update from Kiev. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As tensions build following Russia's movement of troops President Putin marked a national day of

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: celebration. He attended a wreath-laying ceremony on the annual Defender of the Fatherland Day but as the Kremlin was hit with a fresh wave of sanctions from the UK and US Putin reaffirmed that Russia's interests remained non-negotiable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And during a call with Turkey's president, he doubled down on his rhetoric, accusing Ukraine of breaking the Minsk agreement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Nevertheless, despite increasing uncertainty, the Kremlin insists it is still prepared for frank discussions with the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: discussions with the West. Our country is always open to a direct and honest dialogue and ready to search for diplomatic solutions to the most complicated issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I want to repeat that Russia's interests and the security of our people are an indisputable priority.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So we will continue to strengthen and modernize our army and navy, striving to increase their effectiveness so they are fitted out with the most cutting-edge equipment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Galina Polanskaya joins us now from Rostov-on-Don on Russia's border with Eastern Ukraine. Galina,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: always good to see you. So President Putin says that Russia is still open to dialogue but his actions on Monday with the breakaway states and the movement of troops, it appears to say otherwise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: While it was the address of Vladimir Putin to the nation, it was a celebration in Russia, the day of the defense of the fatherhood.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So the message is not about the dialogue, I guess it's the dialogue on Russia's conditions and mostly about the defending i guess it's the dialogue on russia's conditions and mostly about the defending of the fatherland that's the message to the nation and to the west but what we see in reality is that the meeting between uh anthony blink and the u.s secretary of state is cancelled he cancelled it he was supposed to meet with the russian foreign minister sergey lavrov tomorrow they were supposed to discuss a potential meeting between presidents of uh presidents of russia and the united states which is not on the table anymore there is no dialogue russia is withdrawing its diplomats from all of its missions in ukraine and we've heard that vladimir putin spoke with president erdogan and President Erdogan said that Turkey will not tolerate any moves against Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. And Vladimir Putin said that what he did, it was because of Ukrainian aggression in Donbass. So the strategy is very, very clear now. And I don't see any options for the dialogue with the West at this particular moment now Galina you've been speaking to locals on the ground and they seem to support Putin's actions so what have they been telling you well yes I wanted to a town which is located on the border with the Lugansk self-proclaimed separatist Republic the The name of the town is Donetsk, but it's the Russian town. And I spoke with the citizens who helped a lot, those evacuees who were going through the border point, they fed them and they helped them go and find a shelter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So I asked all of those people what they thought about the decision of Vladimir Putin to recognize those republics.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And I was surprised that no one even doubts this decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Everyone thinks that it's good. Let's take a listen of some of their answers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We don't know what's going to happen, whether we will stay alive or not.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So we don't want war. We don't need war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I think that Putin made the right decision, that now people will be protected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I don't think there will be a war like right now with the endless shelling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: These poor people, they've been experiencing this for eight years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: These poor people, they've been experiencing this for eight years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There was a recent poll released by the state pollster, Russian state pollster, which says that actually 73 percent of Russians support the decision of Vladimir Putin, and only 16 percent said that they don't agree.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Galina Polonskaya, thank you so much for that update on the um russian side of things thank you so much now the european union has approved its package of

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: sanctions against russia following president putin's recognition of the two breakaway states in eastern ukraine in london prime minister boris johnson had to defend the sanctions of his government has approved with accusations that they don't go far enough.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now, the EU's measures will target banks financing Russia's military and hundreds of individuals, including high-profile people within President Putin's circle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: For more on EU restrictions, we're now joined by Shona Murray, who's live for us in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So, Shona, the EU's measures that they've now signed off on, they're targeting some pretty high-level individuals within Putin's inner circle.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Tell us more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Yeah, that's right. They were formally agreed today, as we mentioned there, over 300 members of the Russian state Duma, Russian banks and so on. But remember, this is the first level of sanctions that relates to the Russian recognition of breakaway states.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Tomorrow night, there is an emergency summit of EU leaders. All 27 member states will be represented to discuss essentially what's next if and when there is further invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I'm joined now by Bruno Lette, who's an expert, a security expert with the German Marshall Fund. Bruno, these sanctions are the first round. Do you think they'll make any impact? And what happens after that?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, we clearly see that the sanctions today are much more significant than what was on the table in 2014 when Russia annexed Crimea. So the sanctions that we see now aim at three specific things. First of all, it's about preventing anyone to do business with the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk and effectively isolating this territory economically. That's one. Number two, we see that Russian banks are being targeted. Those banks that help to refinance Russian sovereign debt.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: That might make it harder for Russia to finance a war campaign, basically.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And third, we see that a series of individuals around Putin have been targeted with asset freezes and travel bans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Now, this is significant, but these are not yet the sanctions that will cripple Russia economically.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We see that the West has adopted a gradual approach, keeping options in reserve in case Putin decides to further escalate. And what happens next if he does?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I mean, we know that there's a bit of concern over whether the unity that we've seen so far can be maintained, particularly where these sanctions hit specific countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, it's quite obvious that, you know, if Putin escalates, that the West also will need to escalate its own sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So the measures will have to be harsher.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And the harsher the measures towards Russia are, we also need to prepare in Europe or in the West to take our own costs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The problem here is that will Europe remain united?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So far, the EU has remained united on this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But if things get really serious, we know that there are some member states that have some concerns when it comes to energy supplies or capital markets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So this is really the one million dollar question.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: When things get really serious, will the EU remain united?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And what can we expect or hope for in terms of Vladimir Putin's reaction to these sanctions, in terms of them being a deterrent?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Well, we see that Russia has probably been prepared for some of these sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We also know that Russia is prepared to take a cost for its own behavior.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Right now, an important element is also to know that Russia's national sovereign wealth fund is at a record high, estimated at roughly $171 billion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So Russia has also effectively created a financial cushion, if I may say say so a war chest with which it could buy the time so really you know the question is will the current sanctions be enough to to change the russia's behavior knowing that russia is willing to take a cost that is the question okay bruno lette thank you very much for joining us i'm back to studio all right thank you so much that analysis on those EU sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thanks so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, well, we will take a short break, but still to come, more analysis on the deepening crisis in Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Stay tuned.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, sanctions, widespread condemnation and a unified response.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And what greeted Russia's movement of troops into eastern Ukraine and its recognition of the two breakaway separatist regions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But President Putin is standing firm in the face of this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, to discuss what is ahead, we're now joined by Linos Linkavichus, former Minister of Foreign Affairs and of Defence of Lithuania.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Mr. Linkavichus, thank you so much for joining us on the program tonight. Now, you've been really critical of President Putin's insistence that he's open to dialogue. Do you agree with the UK and the US when they say that Putin's move are the start of a Ukrainian invasion? If you would ask Ukrainians, they would tell you that the war started eight years ago and nothing special is happening now, basically. But what he did here a couple of days ago from this historic speech of Putin, he outlined his vision and also his ambition, what he was going to do.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And also we should draw some conclusions that our efforts to stop him so far, they failed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So now it's very important to be united, to make this strong, so to say, pressure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And that was a very important step done by the European Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And it's very important that it was a fast decision, united, also coordinated with the United States, UK, Canada and other players.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But it remains to be seen whether it's sufficient.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Now, Mr. Linkavichus um president putin has been quite dismissive of ukraine's sovereignty president zelinski says that the future of european security will be decided in what is unfolding this is a critical time for ukraine but also for surrounding countries indeed but not just for all the countries I believe it's important also the challenge for all international community for European Union for NATO we're declaring some values we're always saying that we're defending these values and all our it's our foundation of our existence basically but we have to defend values where they are attacked and when they are attacked. And to defend the choice, free choice for sovereign countries to choose the arrangements of their statehood is not just their business, it's also our concern. And that's very important, therefore, to show solidarity, but not only by words, statements, but also to make sure that this country has a right to exist he has the right to be sovereign and has has a right to make a choice do you think that president putin has been surprised by the unified response that we are now seeing i'm afraid he was not surprised what is most important that sanctions so far if you're following what they are talking over the state-controlled media, they are making fun of the sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And I believe even now he believes that this prize is agreeable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And it will not stop him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: He probably believes that these sanctions will not be sufficient as usually and will not be targeted to his cronies, to the close surrounding which was the case so far it's just starting starting starting to to happen and by European Union or by UK getting rid of this golden visas for instance or your American sanctions targeting this very close the oligarchs which are supporting Putin personally and all Kremlin policy. That's exactly something which will give some hope, maybe will be some corrections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But it could be also not the case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But the UK, I mean, they've been criticised for their sanctions package.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Do you think it's gone far enough?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As I said, a lot of space for improvement because we are talking for a long time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You know, this is also the strange nickname that London Grat appears not out of the blue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's because many oligarchs and dirty money and real estate finding property in that capital, also in some other capitals.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: So, so far they felt immune, and this is really time to change.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: While you bring up, you know, time to change, do you think that there is a case for greater integration of Ukraine into both the EU and NATO? Or is that just feeding into what Putin calls Russia's security concerns? First of all, we should understand that when Putin talked, he said how he respects Ukraine, right? And definitely his task to make sure that Ukraine is a failed state and the only future is just in partnering and friendship with russia the future is not possible so our task to make sure that this is wrong that means we have to provide assistance as much as possible in security field in economy and also providing clear european perspective for that country i'm not talking about membership tomorrow but at least i'm talking about a possibility for them to have this choice which is a lot of skepticism before let's be frank on this among some our allies and just the moment of true now we have really to defend the right of that country to make free choice and to be a member of european family mr linkavages we're going to have to leave it there, but thank you so much for your analysis on Euronews tonight. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We are now going to take a short break, but still to come, we're heading over to Matthew in the Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Marianne, we're continuing our coverage by looking at the online warfare of propaganda and cyber attacks. More on that after the break. Soldiers, sanctions and now a state of emergency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has been described as Europe's most dangerous since the Second World War.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But how is the situation being seen online in both Russia and the rest of Europe? Well, Matthew in the Cube has been following that story. Matthew?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Indeed, Mariam. Tensions are heightened between Moscow, Kiev and the West, not just on the ground, but also online, in a warfare of disinformation campaigns and cyber attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: As you heard from Euronews correspondent Sasha Vakhalina, Ukraine says it has once again been hit by a cyber attack affecting many of its ministries and two of the country's largest banks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They say this is similar to previous cyber attacks when Kiev has pointed the finger of blame at Russia. Now the European Union has offered support to Ukraine to combat these kind of threats but as the bloc tries to unite in its stance in Eastern Europe disinformation campaigns against the West are still making inroads and it's by analyzing the online conversation that you can really see the differences. For example this is Google Trends and if you go online around the world and search for either Russia or Ukraine these are some of the most popular search terms. Why is Russia invading Ukraine? Why does Russia want to invade Ukraine? Why does Russia want Ukraine? Many of these portraying Moscow as the aggressor. But contrast that to Yandex, a Russian language search engine based in Moscow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: There if you search for Ukraine you have very different search terms. Here suggesting the former Ukraine, suggesting that it is Kiev who is invading and speaking about the so-called Ukrainian truth. Very different search terms and a very different side of the story that is being portrayed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But that's not the case for everyone on the east of Ukraine. For example, this is a hashtag that has also been trending in Russia on Twitter. It literally translates as the war with Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And online, many younger Russian users have been sharing this hashtag to voice their condemnation of the Kremlin, accusing President Vladimir Putin of scaremongering and warmongering and saying that the situation is, in their words, frightening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So, Marianne, we have seen sanctions and, as you said, a state of emergency, but also, as you can see online, a very divisive war of propaganda at the same time as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It really does look divisive, Matthew. Thank you for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: OK, well, we've reached the end of the programme, but we will leave you with a no comment from Milan, where the Olympic flag arrived ahead of the city's hosting of the Winter Games in 2026.
